Inference of termination conditions for numerical loops

Alexander Serebrenik supported by GOA: ‚ÄúL‚Å¢P+ùêøsuperscriptùëÉ{LP}^{+}italic_L italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: a second gen eration logic programming language‚Äù. ‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉ Danny De Schreye
Abstract

We present a new approach to termination analysis of numerical computations in logic programs. Traditional approaches fail to analyse them due to non well-foundedness of the integers. We present a technique that allows to overcome these difficulties. Our approach is based on transforming a program in way that allows integrating and extending techniques originally developed for analysis of numerical computations in the framework of query-mapping pairs with the well-known framework of acceptability. Such an integration not only contributes to the understanding of termination behaviour of numerical computations, but also allows to perform a correct analysis of such computations automatically, thus, extending previous work on a constraints-based approach to termination. In the last section of the paper we discuss possible extensions of the technique, including incorporating general term orderings.

1 Introduction

Numerical computations form an essential part of almost any real-world program. Clearly, in order for a termination analyser to be of practical use it should contain a mechanism for inferring termination of such computations. However, this topic attracted less attention of the research community. In this work we concentrate on automatic termination inference for logic programs depending on numerical computations. Dershowitz et al.¬†[10] showed that termination of general numerical computations, for instance on floating point numbers, may be contr-intuitive, i.e., the actually observed behaviour does not necessary coincide with the theoretically expected one. Thus, we restrict ourselves to integer computations only.

While discussing termination of integer computations the following question should be asked: what conditions on the queries should be assumed, such that the queries will terminate. We refer to this question as to termination inference problem. We illustrate this notion with the following example:

Example 1
p‚Å¢(X)‚ÜêX<7,X‚Å¢1‚Å¢ùëñùë†‚Å¢X+1,p‚Å¢(X‚Å¢1).formulae-sequence‚Üêùëùùëãùëã7ùëã1ùëñùë†ùëã1ùëùùëã1\displaystyle p(X)\leftarrow X<7,X1\;\mbox{\sl is}\;X+1,p(X1).italic_p ( italic_X ) ‚Üê italic_X < 7 , italic_X 1 is italic_X + 1 , italic_p ( italic_X 1 ) .

This program terminates for queries p‚Å¢(X)ùëùùëãp(X)italic_p ( italic_X ), for all integer values of XùëãXitalic_X. Thus, the answer for the termination inference problem is the condition ‚Äútrue‚Äù. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\hfill\Box‚ñ°

This example also hints why the traditional approaches to termination analysis fail to prove termination of this example. These approaches are mostly based on the notion of level mapping, that is a function from the set of all possible atoms to the natural numbers, and should decrease while traversing the rules. In our case, such a level mapping should depend on XùëãXitalic_X, but XùëãXitalic_X can be negative as well!

Two approaches for solving this problem are possible. First, once can change the definition of the level mapping to map atoms to integers. However, integers are, in general, not well-founded. Thus, to prove termination one should prove that the mapping is to some well-founded subset of integers. In the example above (‚àí‚àû,7)7(-\infty,7)( - ‚àû , 7 ) forms such a subset with an ordering ‚âªsucceeds\succ‚âª, such that x‚âªysucceedsùë•ùë¶x\succ yitalic_x ‚âª italic_y if x<yùë•ùë¶x<yitalic_x < italic_y, with respect to the usual ordering on integers.

The second approach, that we present in the paper, does not require changing the definition of level mapping. Indeed, the level mapping as required exists. It maps p‚Å¢(X)ùëùùëãp(X)italic_p ( italic_X ) to 7‚àíX7ùëã7-X7 - italic_X if X<7ùëã7X<7italic_X < 7 and to 00 otherwise. This level mapping decreases while traversing the rule, i.e., the size of p‚Å¢(X)ùëùùëãp(X)italic_p ( italic_X ), 7‚àíX7ùëã7-X7 - italic_X, is greater than the size of p‚Å¢(X‚Å¢1)ùëùùëã1p(X1)italic_p ( italic_X 1 ), 6‚àíX6ùëã6-X6 - italic_X, thus, proving termination. We present a transformation that allows to define such a level mappings in an automatic way. The transformation presented allows to incorporate techniques of¬†[10], such as level mapping inference, in the well-known framework of the acceptability with respect to a set¬†[7, 8]. This integration provides not only a better understanding of termination behaviour of integer computations, but also the possibility to perform the analysis automatically as in Decorte et al.¬†[9].

The rest of the paper is organised as following. After making some preliminary remarks we present in Section 3 our transformation‚Äîfirst by means of an example, then more formally. In Section 4 we discuss more practical issues and present the algorithm, implementing the termination inference. In Section 5 we discuss further extensions, such as proving termination of programs depending in numerical computations as well as the symbolic ones. Then we review the related work and conclude.

The following proposition characterises LD-termination in terms of acceptability.

Theorem 2.1

(cf.¬†¬†[7]) Let PùëÉPitalic_P be a program. PùëÉPitalic_P is acceptable with respect to a set of atomic queries SùëÜSitalic_S if and only if PùëÉPitalic_P is LD-terminating for all queries in SùëÜSitalic_S.

3 Methodology

In this section we introduce our methodology using a simple example. In the subsequent section we formalise it and discuss different extensions.

Our first example generates an oscillating sequence like ‚àí2,4,‚àí16,‚Ä¶2416‚Ä¶-2,4,-16,\ldots- 2 , 4 , - 16 , ‚Ä¶ and stops if the generated value is greater than 1000100010001000 or smaller than ‚àí10001000-1000- 1000. The treatment is done first on the intuitive level.

Example 2

The intuitive presentation above hints to the major issues to be discussed in the following sections: how the cases as above can be extracted from the program, and how, given the cases extracted, the program should be transformed? Before discussing the answers to these questions we present some basic notions.

3.1 Basic notions

In this section we formally introduce some notions that the further analysis will be based on. Recall that the aim of our analysis, given a predicate and a query, is to find a sufficient condition for termination of this query with respect to this program. Thus, we need to define a notion of a termination condition. To do so we start with a number of auxiliary definitions.

Definition 4

Let pùëùpitalic_p be a predicate of arity nùëõnitalic_n. Then, $1p,‚Ä¶,$npcurrency-dollarsuperscript1ùëù‚Ä¶currency-dollarsuperscriptùëõùëù\$1^{p},\ldots,\$n^{p}$ 1 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , $ italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are called argument positions denominators.

If the predicate is clear from the context the superscripts will be omitted.

Definition 5

Let PùëÉPitalic_P be a program, SùëÜSitalic_S be a set of queries. An argument position iùëñiitalic_i of a predicate pùëùpitalic_p is called integer argument position, if for every p‚Å¢(t1,‚Ä¶,tn)‚ààùê∂ùëéùëôùëô‚Å¢(P,S)ùëùsubscriptùë°1‚Ä¶subscriptùë°ùëõùê∂ùëéùëôùëôùëÉùëÜp(t_{1},\ldots,t_{n})\in\mbox{\sl Call}(P,S)italic_p ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚àà Call ( italic_P , italic_S ), tisubscriptùë°ùëñt_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an integer.

Argument positions denominators corresponding to integer argument positions will be called integer argument positions denominators.

An integer inequality is an atom of one of the following forms Exp1>Exp2Exp1Exp2\mbox{\sl Exp1}>\mbox{\sl Exp2}Exp1 > Exp2, Exp1<Exp2Exp1Exp2\mbox{\sl Exp1}<\mbox{\sl Exp2}Exp1 < Exp2,Exp1‚â•Exp2Exp1Exp2\mbox{\sl Exp1}\geq\mbox{\sl Exp2}Exp1 ‚â• Exp2 or Exp1‚â§Exp2Exp1Exp2\mbox{\sl Exp1}\leq\mbox{\sl Exp2}Exp1 ‚â§ Exp2, where Exp1 and Exp2 are numerical expressions, i.e., are constructed from integers, variables and the four operations of arithmetics. A symbolic inequality over the arguments of a predicate pùëùpitalic_p is constructed similarly to an integer inequality. However, instead of variables, integer argument positions denominators are used.

More formally we define a notion of set of adornments, later we specify when it is guard-tuned and we show how such a guard-tuned set of adornments can be constructed.

3.3 Program transformation

The next question that should be answered is how the program should be transformed given a set of adornments. After this transformation pc‚Å¢(X1,‚Ä¶,Xn)superscriptùëùùëêsubscriptùëã1‚Ä¶subscriptùëãùëõp^{c}(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n})italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) will behave with respect to the transformed program exactly as p‚Å¢(X1,‚Ä¶,Xn)ùëùsubscriptùëã1‚Ä¶subscriptùëãùëõp(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n})italic_p ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) does, for all calls that satisfy the condition cùëêcitalic_c. Intuitively, we replace each call to the predicate pùëùpitalic_p in the original program by a number of possible calls in the transformed one. To define a transformation formally we introduce the following definition:

Let H‚ÜêB1,‚Ä¶,Bn‚Üêùêªsubscriptùêµ1‚Ä¶subscriptùêµùëõH\leftarrow B_{1},\ldots,B_{n}italic_H ‚Üê italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a rule. B1,‚Ä¶,Bisubscriptùêµ1‚Ä¶subscriptùêµùëñB_{1},\ldots,B_{i}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 1‚â§i‚â§n1ùëñùëõ1\leq i\leq n1 ‚â§ italic_i ‚â§ italic_n, is called prefix of the rule, if for all jùëójitalic_j, 1‚â§j‚â§i1ùëóùëñ1\leq j\leq i1 ‚â§ italic_j ‚â§ italic_i, BjsubscriptùêµùëóB_{j}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an integer inequality and the only variables appearing in its arguments are variables of HùêªHitalic_H. B1,‚Ä¶,Bisubscriptùêµ1‚Ä¶subscriptùêµùëñB_{1},\ldots,B_{i}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is called the maximal prefix of the rule, if it is a prefix and B1,‚Ä¶,Bi,Bi+1subscriptùêµ1‚Ä¶subscriptùêµùëñsubscriptùêµùëñ1B_{1},\ldots,B_{i},B_{i+1}italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not a prefix.

Observe, that since a prefix constrains only variables appearing in the head of a clause there exists a symbolic condition over the arguments of the predicate of the head, such that the prefix is its instance with respect to the head. Note, that in general, this symbolic condition is not necessarily unique.

Example 8

Consider the following program: p‚Å¢(X,Y,Y)‚ÜêY>5.‚Üêùëùùëãùëåùëåùëå5p(X,Y,Y)\leftarrow Y>5.italic_p ( italic_X , italic_Y , italic_Y ) ‚Üê italic_Y > 5 . The only prefix of this rule is Y>5ùëå5Y>5italic_Y > 5. There are two symbolic conditions over the arguments of pùëùpitalic_p, $2>5currency-dollar25\$2>5$ 2 > 5 and $3>5currency-dollar35\$3>5$ 3 > 5, such that Y>5ùëå5Y>5italic_Y > 5 is their instance with respect to p‚Å¢(X,Y,Y)ùëùùëãùëåùëåp(X,Y,Y)italic_p ( italic_X , italic_Y , italic_Y ). ‚ñ°‚ñ°\hfill\Box‚ñ°

The following notion, borrowed from [10], guarantees uniqueness of such symbolic conditions. In this case we say that the symbolic condition corresponds to the prefix.

Definition 9

[10] A rule H‚ÜêB1,‚Ä¶,Bn‚Üêùêªsubscriptùêµ1‚Ä¶subscriptùêµùëõH\leftarrow B_{1},\ldots,B_{n}italic_H ‚Üê italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_B start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is called partially normalised if all integer argument positions in HùêªHitalic_H are occupied by distinct variables111If such a rule has only integer arguments Apt et al.¬†[2] call it homogeneous..

We will also say that a program PùëÉPitalic_P is partially normalised if all the rules in PùëÉPitalic_P are partially normalised. After integer argument positions are identified a program can be easily rewritten to partially normalised form.

Now we are ready to present the transformation formally.

Correctness of the transformation should be proved. First of all, finiteness of the number of clauses, the number of subgoals in a clause and the number of elements in an adornment ensures that the transformation always terminates. Second, we need to prove that the transformation preserves termination.

Adorning clauses introduces new predicates. This means that the query QùëÑQitalic_Q gives rise to a number of different queries. Clearly, termination of all of these queries with respect to PasuperscriptùëÉùëéP^{a}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is equivalent to termination of QùëÑQitalic_Q with respect to PasuperscriptùëÉùëéP^{a}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT augmented by a set of the clauses, such that for every p‚âÉùëüùëíùëô‚Å¢(Q)similar-to-or-equalsùëùùëüùëíùëôùëÑp\simeq\mbox{\sl rel}(Q)italic_p ‚âÉ rel ( italic_Q ) and for every A‚ààùíúpùê¥subscriptùíúùëùA\in{\cal A}_{p}italic_A ‚àà caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the clause p‚Å¢(X1,‚Ä¶,Xn)‚ÜêpA‚Å¢(X1,‚Ä¶,Xn)‚Üêùëùsubscriptùëã1‚Ä¶subscriptùëãùëõsuperscriptùëùùê¥subscriptùëã1‚Ä¶subscriptùëãùëõp(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n})\leftarrow p^{A}(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n})italic_p ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ‚Üê italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is added. We call this extended program Pa‚Å¢gsuperscriptùëÉùëéùëîP^{ag}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a italic_g end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Lemma 1

Let PùëÉPitalic_P be a program, and let QùëÑQitalic_Q be a query. Unlike the previous lemma that can be established for an arbitrary set of symbolic conditions, used as adornments, this lemma holds only sets of adornments as defined in Definition¬†8.

4 Practical issues

In the previous section we have shown the transformation that allows reasoning on termination of the numerical computations in the framework of acceptability with respect to the set. In this section we discuss a number of practical issues to be considered for an automated termination analysis.

4.1 Guard-tuned sets of adornments

In Example¬†7 we have seen two different sets of adornments. Both of them are valid according to Definition¬†8. However, {‚àí1000<$1<‚àí1,1<$1<1000,($1‚â§‚àí1000)‚à®(‚àí1‚â§$1‚â§1)‚à®($1‚â•1000)}formulae-sequence1000currency-dollar111currency-dollar11000currency-dollar110001currency-dollar11currency-dollar11000\{-1000<\$1<-1,1<\$1<1000,(\$1\leq-1000)\vee(-1\leq\$1\leq 1)\vee(\$1\geq 1000)\}{ - 1000 < $ 1 < - 1 , 1 < $ 1 < 1000 , ( $ 1 ‚â§ - 1000 ) ‚à® ( - 1 ‚â§ $ 1 ‚â§ 1 ) ‚à® ( $ 1 ‚â• 1000 ) } is in some sense preferable to {$1‚â§100,$1>100}formulae-sequencecurrency-dollar1100currency-dollar1100\{\$1\leq 100,\$1>100\}{ $ 1 ‚â§ 100 , $ 1 > 100 }. There is a number of reasons to prefer the first set to the second one. First of all, it has a declarative reading: the sets that are constructed are related to the constraints in the bodies of the clauses and in fact express conditions that, when satisfied, allow to traverse the rule. Second, comparing the two adorned programs in Example¬†9 one might observe that the second program has two mutually recursive predicates, connected by two clauses, while the first program has not only this connection, but also self-loop on one of the predicates.

Intuitively, a set of adornments of a predicate pùëùpitalic_p is guard-tuned if for every adornment aùëéaitalic_a in it and every clause cùëêcitalic_c of the program defining pùëùpitalic_p the conjunction of the maximal prefix of cùëêcitalic_c and aùëéaitalic_a is either false or the conjunction is identical to aùëéaitalic_a. We will see that the set of adornments we preferred in the discussion above is guard-tuned, while the second set is not.

Definition 11

Let PùëÉPitalic_P be a partially normalised program, let pùëùpitalic_p be a predicate in PùëÉPitalic_P, and let ùíúpsubscriptùíúùëù{\cal A}_{p}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a set of adornments for pùëùpitalic_p. We say that ùíúpsubscriptùíúùëù{\cal A}_{p}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is guard-tuned if for every A‚ààùíúpùê¥subscriptùíúùëùA\in{\cal A}_{p}italic_A ‚àà caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and for every rule r‚ààPùëüùëÉr\in Pitalic_r ‚àà italic_P with the symbolic condition cùëêcitalic_c corresponding to the maximal prefix of rùëüritalic_r holds that either c‚àßA=ùëìùëéùëôùë†ùëíùëêùê¥ùëìùëéùëôùë†ùëíc\wedge A=\mbox{\sl false}italic_c ‚àß italic_A = false or c‚àßA=Aùëêùê¥ùê¥c\wedge A=Aitalic_c ‚àß italic_A = italic_A.

Example 13

Consider the sets of adornments presented in Example¬†7. The first set of adornments is not guard-tuned while the second one is guard-tuned. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\hfill\Box‚ñ°

4.2 How to construct a guard-tuned set of adornments?

In this subsection we present a technique allowing to construct a guard-tuned set of adornments for a predicate pùëùpitalic_p given a program PùëÉPitalic_P. To do so, recall once more Examples¬†7 and 13. They suggest two ways of constructing such a set. The first one is: given a program PùëÉPitalic_P collect the symbolic conditions, corresponding to the maximal prefixes of the rules defining pùëùpitalic_p (we denote this set ùíûpsubscriptùíûùëù{\cal C}_{p}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and add the completion of the constructed disjunction. Unfortunately, this set of conditions is not necessarily a set of adornments and if so, it is not necessary guard-tuned.

Example 14

Consider the following program.

r‚Å¢(X)‚ÜêX>5.‚Üêùëüùëãùëã5\displaystyle r(X)\leftarrow X>5.italic_r ( italic_X ) ‚Üê italic_X > 5 .
r‚Å¢(X)‚ÜêX>10,r‚Å¢(X).formulae-sequence‚Üêùëüùëãùëã10ùëüùëã\displaystyle r(X)\leftarrow X>10,r(X).italic_r ( italic_X ) ‚Üê italic_X > 10 , italic_r ( italic_X ) .

Thus, we are going to use a different approach. Once more, we start by finding ùíûpsubscriptùíûùëù{\cal C}_{p}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let ùíûp=c1,‚Ä¶,cnsubscriptùíûùëùsubscriptùëê1‚Ä¶subscriptùëêùëõ{\cal C}_{p}=c_{1},\ldots,c_{n}caligraphic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚Ä¶ , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then let ùíúpsubscriptùíúùëù{\cal A}_{p}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the set of conjunctions of cisubscriptùëêùëñc_{i}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT‚Äôs and their negations. We claim that the constructed set is always a guard-tuned set of adornments. Before stating this formally, consider once more Example¬†14.

Lemma 3

Let PùëÉPitalic_P be a program, pùëùpitalic_p be a predicate in PùëÉPitalic_P and ùíúpsubscriptùíúùëù{\cal A}_{p}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be constructed as described. Proof

The proof is immediate by checking the definitions ‚ñ†‚ñ†\hfill\blacksquare‚ñ†

4.3 How to define a level mapping?

One of the questions that should be answered is how the level mappings should be generated automatically. The problem with defining level mappings is that they should reflect changes on possibly negative integer arguments, on the one hand, and remain non-negative, on the other. We also like to remain in the framework of level mappings on atoms defined as linear combinations of sizes of their arguments.

We are going to solve this problem by defining different level mappings for different adorned versions of the predicate. The major observation underlying the technique presented in this subsection is that if $1>$2currency-dollar1currency-dollar2\$1>\$2$ 1 > $ 2 appears in the adornment of a recursive clause, then for each call to this adorned predicate $1‚àí$2currency-dollar1currency-dollar2\$1-\$2$ 1 - $ 2 will be positive, and thus, can be used for defining a level mapping. More formally:

Technique developed by Decorte et al.¬†[9] allows to define symbolic counterparts of the level mappings and to infer the actual values of the coefficients by solving a system of constraints.

4.4 Putting it all together and inferring termination constraints

In this section we show how the steps studied so far can be combined to an algorithm that allows to infer termination conditions. Intuitively, one starts with a termination condition initialised to be true, i.e., assuming that query QùëÑQitalic_Q terminates with respect to a program PùëÉPitalic_P for all possible values of integer arguments. Constraints are constructed similarly to¬†[9]. If these can be satisfied without imposing any additional constraints on the integer variables, stop and report termination for the condition constructed so far. If these impose some constraints involving a new integer variable, repeat the process. If neither of the cases hold, stop and report possibility of non-termination.

Any other technique proving termination and being able not only to claim ‚Äútermination can be proved‚Äù or ‚Äútermination cannot be proved‚Äù but also providing in the latter case some constraint that, if satisfied, implies termination can be used instead of¬†[9]. The algorithm is presented in Figure¬†1.

In order to prove correctness of this algorithm we have to prove its termination and partial correctness, i.e., that the symbolic condition constructed is a termination condition. Termination of the algorithm follows from termination of its steps discussed earlier and from the finiteness of the number of integer variables, restricting a number of possible jumps. Partial correctness follows from the correctness of transformations and the corresponding result of¬†[9]. Observe that after removing ‚Äúirrelevant clauses‚Äù the non-terminating (for some query) program might became terminating for it. However, this transformation expresses the meaning of termination condition: if cùëêcitalic_c holds, clauses defining predicates such that their adornments are inconsistent with cùëêcitalic_c can not be unified with QùëÑQitalic_Q. Observe also, that at the first traversal of the algorithm (c=ùë°ùëüùë¢ùëíùëêùë°ùëüùë¢ùëíc=\mbox{\sl true}italic_c = true), if PùëÉPitalic_P does not have an unreachable code, this step does not change PasuperscriptùëÉùëéP^{a}italic_P start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

5 Further extensions

In this section we discuss possible extensions of the algorithm presented above. First of all we re-consider inference of adornments, then we discuss integrating termination analysis of numerical and symbolic computations.

5.1 Once more about the inference of adornments

The set of adornments ùíúpsubscriptùíúùëù{\cal A}_{p}caligraphic_A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, inferred in Subsection¬†4.2 may sometimes be to week for inferring precise termination conditions, as the following example illustrates.

Example 18

Consider the following program:

p‚Å¢(X,Y)‚ÜêX<0,Y‚Å¢1‚Å¢ùëñùë†‚Å¢Y+1,p‚Å¢(Y‚Å¢1,X).formulae-sequence‚Üêùëùùëãùëåùëã0ùëå1ùëñùë†ùëå1ùëùùëå1ùëã\displaystyle p(X,Y)\leftarrow X<0,Y1\;\mbox{\sl is}\;Y+1,p(Y1,X).italic_p ( italic_X , italic_Y ) ‚Üê italic_X < 0 , italic_Y 1 is italic_Y + 1 , italic_p ( italic_Y 1 , italic_X ) .

An alternative approach to propagating such an information was suggested in¬†[10]. 5.2 Integrating numerical and symbolic computation

As already claimed in the Introduction numerical computations form an essential part of almost any real-world program. Sometimes, such computation is ‚Äúpure numerical‚Äù, that is does not involve any reasoning on the symbolic level, such as in the examples above. However, sometimes numerical computation is interleaved with a symbolic one as illustrated by the following example, collecting leaves of a tree with a variable branching factor, being a common data structure in natural language processing¬†[15].

To prove termination of queries {ùëêùëúùëôùëôùëíùëêùë°‚Å¢(t,v,[])}ùëêùëúùëôùëôùëíùëêùë°ùë°ùë£\{\mbox{\sl collect}(t,v,[])\}{ collect ( italic_t , italic_v , [ ] ) }, where tùë°titalic_t is a tree and vùë£vitalic_v is a variable, the following three decreases should be shown: between a call to collect and a call to process in the second clause, between a call to process and a call to collect in the fourth one and between two calls to process in the same clause. The first and the second decreases can be shown only by a symbolic level mapping, the third one‚Äîonly by the numerical approach. ‚ñ°‚ñ°\hfill\Box‚ñ°

Thus, our goal is to combine the existing symbolic approaches with the numerical one presented so far. One of the possible ways to do so is to combine two level mappings, ‚à£‚ãÖ‚à£1\mid\cdot\mid_{1}‚à£ ‚ãÖ ‚à£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ‚à£‚ãÖ‚à£2\mid\cdot\mid_{2}‚à£ ‚ãÖ ‚à£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for example, by mapping each atom A‚ààBPEùê¥subscriptsuperscriptùêµùê∏ùëÉA\in B^{E}_{P}italic_A ‚àà italic_B start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_E end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to a pair of natural numbers (‚à£A‚à£1,‚à£A‚à£2)subscriptdelimited-‚à£‚à£ùê¥1subscriptdelimited-‚à£‚à£ùê¥2(\mid\!A\mid_{1},\mid\!A\mid_{2})( ‚à£ italic_A ‚à£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ‚à£ italic_A ‚à£ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Then an ordering relation on the atoms can be defined, based on the lexicographic ordering of such pairs. Well-foundedness of the natural numbers implies that this ordering is well-founded and the framework of term-acceptability¬†[18], allows to reason on termination of programs in terms of decreases on such orderings.

This integrated approach allows to analyse correctly examples such as ground, unify, numbervars¬†[19] and Example 6.12 in¬†[10]. Moreover, some numerical examples, such as Ackermann‚Äôs function, that cannot be analysed by extending¬†[9] due to the limitations of level mappings defined as linear combinations, can be analysed by the integrated approach.

6 Conclusion

Termination of numerical computations was studied by a number of authors¬†[1, 2, 10]. Apt et al.¬†[2] provided a declarative semantics, so called ŒòŒò\Thetaroman_Œò-semantics, for Prolog programs with first-order built-in, including arithmetic operations. In this framework the property of strong termination, i.e., finiteness of all LD-trees for all possible goals, was completely characterised based on appropriately tuned notion of acceptability. This approach provides important theoretical results, but seems to be difficult to integrate in automatic tools. In¬†[1] it is claimed that an unchanged acceptability condition can be applied to programs in pure Prolog with arithmetic by defining the level mappings on ground atoms with the arithmetic relation to be zero. This approach ignores the actual computation, and thus, its applicability is restricted to programs using some arithmetics but not really relaying on them, such as quicksort. Moreover, as Example¬†17 illustrates there are many programs that terminate only for some queries. Alternatively, Dershowitz et al.¬†[10] extended the query-mapping pairs formalism of¬†[12] to deal with numerical computations. However, this approach inherited the disadvantages of¬†[12], such as high computational price, as well.

More research has been done on termination analysis for constraint logic programs¬†[5, 14, 16, 17]. Since numerical computations in Prolog should be written in a way that allows a system to verify their satisfiability we can see numerical computations of Prolog as an ideal constraint system. Thus, all the results obtained for ideal constraints systems can be applied. Unfortunately, the research was either oriented towards theoretical characterisations¬†[16, 17] or restricted to domains isomorphic to ùí©ùí©{\cal N}caligraphic_N, such as trees and terms¬†[14].

In a contrast to the approach of¬†[10] that was restricted to verifying termination, we presented a methodology for inferring termination conditions. It is not clear whether and how¬†[10] can be extended to infer such conditions. A main contribution of this work to the theoretical understanding of termination of numerical computations is in situating them in the well-known framework of acceptability and allowing integration with the existing approaches to termination of symbolic computations. The methodology presented can be integrated in automatic termination analysers, such as¬†[9].

The kernel technique is powerful enough to analyse correctly examples such as gcd and mod¬†[10], all examples appearing in the dedicated to arithmetic Chapter 8 of¬†[19], also being a superset of arithmetical examples appearing in¬†[1]. Moreover, our approach gains its power from the underlying framework of¬†[9] and thus, allows to prove termination of some examples that cannot be analysed correctly by¬†[10], similar to confused delete¬†[6, 9]. The extended technique, presented in Section 5, allows to analyse correctly examples such as Ackermann‚Äôs function, ground, unify, numbervars¬†[19] and Example 6.12 in¬†[10].

As a future work we consider a complete implementation of the algorithm. Due to the use of the constraint solving techniques we expect it both to be powerful and highly efficient.
